awd_titl_txt: A General and Robust Route to Highly Diverse Hollow Nanostructures with New Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary 

Nanoscale materials with hollow interiors (i.e., hollow nanomaterials) are critical components in many areas of science and technology. The properties of hollow nanomaterials and their usefulness in applications such as biosensing and catalysis have strong dependence on their detailed structure such as shape and elemental composition and can be different than those of solid particles of the same size. Nevertheless, it has been a challenge to finely control the structure of a hollow nanomaterial in chemical synthesis. The goal of this project, which is jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program and the Metals and Metallic Nanostructures program, both in the Division of Materials Research, is to establish a general and effective method to synthesize hollow nanomaterials with controllable structures and new properties.  In addition to synthesizing new materials, this project examines properties such as thermal stability and unusual interactions with light that will be important for eventual applications.  This project provides multidisciplinary research training for graduate and undergraduate students particularly from underrepresented groups. Through a new NanoAmbassadors program, undergraduate students will be involved in outreach on nanomaterials at their former high schools.  The project also provides high school students with summer research opportunities.

Technical Summary

Hollow nanomaterials have found widespread uses in many areas, including biomedicine, imaging, sensing, catalysis and electronics. Controlling the structure of hollow nanostructures is an effective approach to tailoring their physicochemical properties. The proposed work, which is jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program and the Metals and Metallic Nanostructures program, both in the Division of Materials Research, seeks to develop a general and robust method to precisely control the structure of hollow nanomaterials. This method relies on alternating processes of galvanic replacement reactions and sacrificial template regeneration. As examples, design and synthesis of hollow nanostructures made of gold, silver, platinum, palladium, copper, and materials containing multiple metals are being demonstrated. A series of hollow nanostructures with diverse structures and new properties are being generated. Detailed structures of the hollow nanomaterials and their structural responses to heating are revealed with high-performance electron microscopy. Plasmonic properties of the nanomaterials are investigated using both experimental measurements and computational simulations. This project will benefit the engagement of graduate and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, in research. The research is also integrated into outreach activities for K-12 students.  Through a new NanoAmbassadors program, undergraduate students will be involved in outreach on nanomaterials at their former high schools.  The project also provides high school students with summer research opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Metallic nanoscale materials with hollow interiors (i.e., hollow nanostructures) have found widespread applications in various fields such as catalysis, imaging, sensing, and biomedicine. The performance of a metallic hollow nanostructure in certain applications has a strong dependence on its morphology (e.g., wall thickness and internal structure) and elemental composition. Galvanic replacement, a redox process that involves the oxidation of one metal template by the ions of another metal having a higher reduction potential, represents a classic and effective method to synthesize metallic hollow nanostructures. However, the hollow nanostructures prepared by conventional galvanic replacement have fixed morphologies and elemental compositions with limited turnabilities, which is determined by the inherent reaction stoichiometry of galvanic replacement. This limitation inhibits the design and synthesis of hollow nanostructures with desired morphologies and compositions suitable for certain applications.

In this project, the research team proposed to develop a general and robust approach based on regeneration of sacrificial template to break the confinement of reaction stoichiometry in galvanic replacement, and thus produce hollow nanostructures with tunable morphologies and compositions. We also investigate the properties (e.g., plasmonic activity and stability) of these hollow nanostructures with diverse physical and chemical parameters. Moreover, to demonstrate potential uses of the unique hollow nanostructures produced in this project, we applied them to biosensing applications.

One significant fundamental outcome of this project is that we have been able to finely control the physical/chemical parameters (such as wall thickness, internal structure, and elemental composition) of hollow nanostructures in experiments. Such controls were backed up with clear mechanistic understanding. We found that the key was to carefully manipulate the regeneration of sacrificial templates that allows for continuous galvanic replacement with one or more types of metal ions. Our synthetic method was successfully applied to multiple metallic systems involving silver (Ag), gold (Au), palladium (Pd), and/or platinum (Pt). Another key fundamental outcome of this project is that we have found interesting and important structure-property relationships. For example, in one study, we have systematically investigated the role played by wall thickness in determining the plasmonic properties of hollow nanostructures. Significantly, we have gained quantitative understanding on the relationship between wall thickness and plasmonic activity. In another study, we have demonstrated that the plasmonic activities (particularly the major localized surface plasmon resonance peak) of Ag-Au hollow nanostructures can be effectively tuned by controlling their internal structures. Moreover, meaningful fundamental outcomes were obtained from the stability studies of hollow nanostructures. For instance, we found that thermal stability of Ag-Au hollow nanocages was enhanced as their wall thickness was increased. Notably, in most of the aforementioned fundamental studies, we used high-performance electron microscopes to characterize and monitor the nanostructures, which offered valuable insights at the atomic precision. In addition, we performed computational simulations to understand the experimental findings. These fundamental outcomes will serve as a solid foundation to inspire future research work in the fields of materials science and nanotechnology.

With regard to the technical aspect of the outcomes, we have demonstrated potential biomedical application of as-synthesized hollow nanostructures with unique properties. For instance, the Ag-Au nanocages with controlled internal structures were applied to detection of human carcinoembryonic antigen (a biomarker for colorectal cancer) that achieved low detection limits. In a recent study, we have used plasmonic hollow nanostructures as labels for lateral flow assay, a point-of-care diagnostic technique.

Overall, this research project contributed to the development of a diverse spectrum of hollow nanostructures that can be applied to many current and emerging areas of technology. The project provided training for graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Central Florida and University of Texas at Dallas. The project also offered K-12 students hands-on research experiences and fostered their interest in science and engineering.


Last Modified: 09/16/2024
Modified by: Xiaohu Xia
